ANNE RICHARDS, CEO, M&G INVESTMENTS; AND FRANCISCO JERONIMO, SENIOR RESEARCH DIRECTOR, IDC; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB SURVEILLANCE

MAY 02, 2018

SPEAKERS: ANNE RICHARDS, CEO, M&G INVESTMENTS

FRANCISCO JERONIMO, SENIOR RESEARCH DIRECTOR, IDC

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: We're very pleased to be joined for the hour by Anne Richards. She is the Chief Executive of M&G Investments. And as always, you make us smarter, so thank you so much for coming on. What do you need from J. Powell? Is it more of an indication of kind of forward- looking of how many rate hikes? Is it something on the inverted yield curve and what that means as it happens or discontinuity?

ANNE RICHARDS, CEO, M&G INVESTMENTS: I think just no surprises. I think people are not expecting any fireworks and I think delivering that would be actually a good underpinning to the markets, particularly after the volatility that we saw in the first quarter, and that change and tone of the markets where you saw bonds and equities both moving down rather than up. So that increased volatility, that correlation of the wrong way, the way that people don't like correlations to go. So I think the fed here -- we've had those interest rate rises up to now, market isn't expecting anything, no surprises will be good results.

LACQUA: What is the fed's main dilemma right now?

RICHARDS: Well, I mean, feds always have dilemma about the path of growth, about the expectations of markets, about inflation. Actually, corporate earnings are doing pretty well. They've been ahead of expectations. Inflation, we've got enough inflation. It doesn't look like we have too much inflation. We're kind of on target on inflation, I would say. So I don't think there are too many dilemmas. I think that the challenge is simply don't do a misstep that spooks anybody at this point, particularly when you set this in a wider context, so a lot of uncertainty around trade, around some of the geopolitical relationships. I think the mantra is don't mess up here, stead as she goes.

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Anne, when you look at the M&G Investments and when you look at the mathematics of bond bear markets, I believe that is yield higher, prices lower. It's never a smooth gradient, there're always jump conditions. What are the kinds of jump conditions that we could see in the bond market where we get jumps in yield and lower prices suddenly?

RICHARDS: So it's this -- always against this backdrop, there're stuffs that could happen that would shock the market into doing different things. It's very hard to predict what those are in advance, which is a tripe thing to say. We all know that. But we have -- we are moving this year from a position of net bond purchasing by central banks to a situation where we've got net bond issuance right around the world. And the market is still adjusting to what that looks and feel like. Actually, you've got a big buyer who is no longer going to be buying, if you like, right around the world. And I think that is the tipping point. It's about the demand and supply for those bond issues that are out there. So I think, to me, that is the big one that we're navigating this year. It is a different backdrop to bond markets, in general.

KEENE: Yes. Francine, this is really important on what she just said. Anne Richards goes down microeconomic principles when you look at a big macroeconomic view from 30,000 feet, I think. I really agree with that, that this is about microeconomics here forward for Chairman Powell.

LACQUA: It is, Tom. But if we bring it back to the markets, Anne, what do clients want? I mean, what kind of strategies do they ask of you?

RICHARDS: So I think smoothing has definitely been something. I mean, people have got quite used to this relatively low volatile world, at least in listed markets and so -- and conventional markets. You could argue, there has been a lot of volatility. Non-conventional markets like digital currencies and Bitcoin, all of that sort of stuff. But conventional markets, volatility really had become very subdued. And suddenly there's been that shock back into volatility worlds. So removing that volatility, so trying to seek out where you have counter-correlated assets to kind of smooth that path is definitely one of the things that people are out there. Having said that, I think a lot of people are look at the underlying power of earnings that we've got through coming from the corporate sector. And looking at the trade-off of the risks that you now see and still not again a lot of real yield out of bond markets and still getting quite a powerhouse in terms of earning growth from equity markets and saying, actually, the price of our extra volatility and equity markets might be worth paying because you can really see the fundamentals coming through. So I think there's a number of -- it really depends always on utility curves, preferences. What is it that is most important to individuals? And there's no one summary you can say, all individuals want this or all individuals want that. So I think those are two of themes that we would see coming through in conversations with clients.

LACQUA: I mean, has the conversation shifted in the last couple of weeks because there's a little bit of a slowdown in economic growth worldwide? And actually, what does that mean again for a market sentiment in the future and the correlation with monetary policy?

RICHARDS: It's fascinating actually. See, people -- how quickly sentiment changes and what people talk about. So some of those things that I just perceive that people are suddenly talking about again, gold has come back, but inflation, gold. Suddenly -- we didn't talk about that six months ago. Suddenly, that's back on the conversation again. So that's one thing. I think that the oil price, frankly, is another. You've seen the oil price, which everybody said was very subdued for a very long period of time. And it sort of snuck up on us instead of gradually, gradually, gradually been moving into territory where despite the fact that you've not seen the investment really start go back in again. Actually, the economics start to make that more appealing. So there's mentioned in conversations around oil price commodities and the knock-on effects of that. So I think we're going to see a change in tone in some of those conversations. The whole tech conversation of what does a successful business model look like in technology. Again, 2016-2017, big tech was winner almost regardless of what it did. Much more discrimination coming into the conversations with clients about what a good business model is, what a bad business model is and (inaudible).

KEENE: Anne Richards, Megan Greene writing in the FT today on where is inflation, we're all waiting for it. I guess we'll hear about it in the non-press conference today at the debt (ph) meeting. Where is the inflation?

RICHARDS: Gosh, what an interesting question. Inflation comes in all sorts of different places and unexpected places, I think. So conventional inflation is varying country-by-country, market-by-market quite significantly, oil price will be feeding through into inflation numbers, that's absolutely the case. But on the other hand, if you see what's happening on the retail high street, you can see the high street is challenged still by falling process in many areas, where on the other side coin, you've got internet prices actually going up in some respect. So you've got some quite an interesting contrast there. So I think, overall in inflation, it's still a very difficult picture, I think, for anybody to grasp the totality of it. So oil price starting to feed through is definitely one, and some of the big currency moves, you're actually seeing currency induced inflation rather than fundamental underlying inflation.

KEENE: Exactly. Well, that's one of our themes here through Surveillance this morning. Anne Richards with us with the M&G Investment.

LACQUA: We're back with Anne Richards, Chief Executive of M&G Investments. Anne, when you look at again what your clients want, how you position on your portfolios, trade tensions seemed to be on the back of it because at least Steve Mnuchin is showing up in a couple of hours I think to try and discuss, is this still the main risk for the world economy or is it monetary policy?

RICHARDS: It's (inaudible). So I think trade is clearly out there as something that people are concerned about because the global economy, in terms of the totality of the pie, if you like, has been expanded over recent decades by global trades. That's been the big driver of much of the global expansion. So if that is really under threat, then there is a risk that we end up fighting over a smaller -- a share of the smaller pie as opposed to it. And I think that is the concern that's out there. Having said all of that, the way that America has been conducting trade policy negotiations, and indeed other international negotiations has been about ripping up the playbook, throwing everything up in the air, getting everybody uncertain and then coming to a compromise at the last minute, and you can see that. And a classic example of that is the way the North and South Korea conversations are going. Whereas if you think back to last year, it was all about who was going to hit the big the red button first. And now, we actually have come far farther than anyone ever anticipated than we would have done a year ago. So I think there's a little bit around this whole global trade tariffs conversation which will affect -- will be affected in the same way ultimately. On the European thing, I just absolutely do not believe that the U.S. wants to mess up relationship with Europe. But President Trump clearly wants to get the maximum that it possibly can out of any bartering that it does with Europe, hence, the conversations that have been had with Mr. Macron, with Mrs. Merkel over the last week or so. So I think that's what we're going to play out and I think most of that, as when we look at it, think that that is the central scenario. But in that sense (ph), there are risks.

LACQUA: Do you worry about European growth having peaked? We're seeing -- again, the data is not that clear actually, right? It depends on kind of some of the PMIs are better than expected in certain countries, worse than expecting others, should we assume that it doesn't get any better than this for your portfolios?

RICHARDS: Well, I think on Europe. I mean, I think there are still a lot of things that are going in the right direction. But there have been a few things which have come together simultaneously. People are starting to get concerned about the impact of Brexit on Mainland Europe. That wasn't a concern. That is beginning to be a little bit of a concern. You will see people deferring or shaping some of their investment plans because of that. So that will have a feed through on that. The fact that in Germany and France and Italy, so with the big three countries there, there are political tensions and relatively unclear and insecure governments in different forms and shapes in place there. Again, it doesn't help the view that we're going to get a kind of coordinated negotiated settlement on anything very much. So there were a few things in the background that just make people feel a little bit less comfortable than they did six months ago in Europe. But actually, the direction of travel is still okay.

KEENE: Anne Richards, Martin Wolf and the FT with a brilliant walkthrough of China's attitude as the U.S. officials travel to China, I guess, to have a big argument on trade. What does it mean for your international investment at M&G? Do you lighten up or is this an opportunity to acquire Pacific Rim shares?

RICHARDS: So, look, on the whole China story and what is being driven through that China story, I think the -- you are seeing a change yet again in the outreach that's coming out of China. And that is very, very powerful. So the ability of business to get direct access to markets that it was not able to get direct access to before in China has been -- that's a very significant announcement. The fact that she is in place for much longer than might have been anticipated and will be continuing to drive forward in that economic empowering, I think, creates a very positive backdrop to what's going on in China. So I think we would remain positive on the direction of travel

LACQUA: Anne, thank you so much. Anne Richards there of M&G stays with us.

Joining us now is Francisco Jeronimo, IDC Senior Research Director for European mobile devices and Anne Richards of M&G Investments where she's Chief Executive. So thank you both for coming on the program. Francisco, what do we learn about Apple?

FRANCISCO JERONIMO, SENIOR RESEARCH DIRECTOR, IDC: We learned that a powerful brand continues to perform when they continue to deliver value that consumers perceived as something that improves overtime. And after ten years when the first -- after the first -- the launch of the first iPhone, and when the market is already contracting. And then last year, the decline for the first time, the smart phone, Apple delivering these kinds of results at a higher price point, it's remarkable and definitely a stellar quarter for Apple.

LACQUA: Francisco, let me talk to you about the iPhone and then I want to ask Anne a little bit about the financial surrounding Apple. But if you look at the iPhone year-on-year revenue growth -- Tom, bear with me. I know you don't like candle charts, but this is a really good one. We heard from the Chief Executive of Apple saying, look, iPhone X was stellar, best performing, but that's what you'd expect. How does he continue on this trend in the quarters to come?

JERONIMO: That's a challenge for them. Of course, it's a challenge. But it really shows that the brand proposition and then the perception of the consumers and enterprises also have about Apple is not just about the good looking iPhones, it's about everything that comes with the device. The ecosystem and all the services and also a very important topic that he mentioned in the call, the privacy and security, and indeed IDC did a recent survey to enterprise in Europe. And we found out that the top reason that why enterprises choose an iPhone is because of security and the perception that an iPhone brings around security. And this is a very important value for consumers and enterprises in the smart phone, particularly nowadays with all the news and the candles (ph) around privacy leaks and all of those problems.

LACQUA: Yes. We can take about Facebook. We also need to talk about Snap. I know I'm going to find Tom on Snap. I'm sure it's like #tomtom or something like that. He's keeping it secret. Anne, when you look at Apple, they have a lot of cash. And finally, they're returning it to shareholders. Do you like the stock (inaudible)?

RICHARDS: So hundred billion coming back to shareholders, I mean, that can be quite nice. That could be quite nice for markets that's putting a lot of liquidity into the system. There's a lot of central banks that would like that sort of money, I think, knocking around. So I think that it's tremendous. But I think the thing you have to remember with Apple is its maturity as a business is showing through. And I don't mean maturity in terms of the product range. But actually it's grown up company that has proper mechanisms in place. It's not trying to make this up as it has got larger -- unexpectedly larger, like some of the newer competitors in the general social media tech space. You really see that strength coming through. And what's fascinating to me is that it's still innovating but its innovation is not a product book. It is in that ecosystem, exactly as you mentioned. It is in the services that it's persuading us all to subscribe to. And it's been very, very successful in doing that. Service revenue is now really significant proportion of the overall mix. So I think when you look in the round (ph), I mean, Apple at this valuation at this point, it takes a strong stomach. We don't have very much exposure to it. But nonetheless, I think you've got to give credit to it for its ability to continue to innovate in different ways with this business model.

KEENE: That was so brilliant, folks, with the mathematics of Anne Richards that we're going to stop the show, show a chart and continue with the mathematician from Edinboro and the engineer from Edinboro. She used the word, maturity. Okay. So, Anne, this on a second derivative basis is logged (ph) concave. The media is hardwired to long convex, IDC, Francisco's company has been brilliant with a tempered view. Is Apply basically tending towards a utility-like cash flow, Anne Richards, which goes to the maturity of that concave chart? I mean, they're not the normal growth company anymore, are they? They are just, as you say, a mature company.

RICHARDS: So they're a mature company. I would probably go with the view that they're a mature and growing company, so a company that is not going through the stellar almost exponential growth that you see, and we might come and talk back about Snap and how that works in reverse as well. But I think you've got to give a lot of credit to Apple that it is managing to innovate its business model and that is coming through in a much more robust and sustainable model than you see in some of the (inaudible). Now, valuation is a different thing. But nonetheless, (inaudible) business model looks sustainable.

KEENE: Okay. This is brilliant, folks. We've got a major financial accent in Anne Richards and Francisco Jeronimo working with IDC. Francisco, help us with the unit partial differentials as you go up the cell phone price point. The Apple gloom and doom crew says the iPhone X costs too much, baloney, they're selling them like crazy. Where is the tip point per unit? Is it $900? Is it $700? Where is the tip point where expensive phones become a gravy train?

JERONIMO: The tipping point is when there is no additional value that consumers are willing or are getting from a product. The criticisms that we hear today about the iPhone X is exactly the same criticism that we heard in 2007 when they launched the first iPhone. Everyone was saying, this is crazy, launching a smart phone at this price point when the average selling smart phone at that time were much lower, and it's exactly the same. Of course, it doesn't Apple can continue to stretch the prices up because there's definitely a limit where consumers will ask themselves whether it's worth paying for that kind of device or not. But at the moment, Apple continues to do very well and the $1,000 price tag continues to be an achievable average selling price for their projects in the next quarters. However, the market is contracting. So even if Apple wants to sell less products or sell less products at a higher price point, there's a limit because the market is not growing for every single person around the world and in regions where people cannot afford these kinds price points as Apple continues to do and invest in the older versions of their devices and pushing those previous to those consumers at lower price points. But clearly, if the value is there, consumers are willing to pay.

LACQUA: Anne, talk to me about Facebook. So they're going into a dating app which actually a lot of their dating ventures (ph) are more (inaudible) about. And this is Snap. So Snap was down, I think, 18% of premarket trade because their redesign isn't working. I mean, what happened to Snap?

RICHARDS: Well, it's burning through cash at a rate. It's got a lot of cash on its balance sheet. So I think it's a time cash burn story. Can it turn around the use of experience in such a way that it actually starts to put on user growth at the same rate as it did before and get the ad revenue going to support it before it runs out of cash? And we've seen loads of business. They're not usually this big when they go through this but this is a very classic program. And I think that's the situation that we're in with Snap at the moment.

KEENE: Well, go ahead, Anne. Please continue.

RICHARDS: No, I was going to say what I think what's interesting when you see that the Facebook, the dating app, and we see Google's recent announcement, even you see Apple talking about what it's doing with Apple Watch and thinking about health. The ecosystem argument is definitely leeching out all of these companies and thinking how do we expand from our simple one product, one business model ad revenue fuelled model into something that is expanding. And I think at this stage, we don't know who is going to be the winner in this. But certainly the companies that are trying to do something different are more likely to succeed than those that aren't.

KEENE: I can't say enough how valuable this was. Anne Richards with us with M&G. Francisco Jeronimo, thank you so much, with IDC. I look forward to speaking to you with John Farrell on Bloomberg Radio here in a bit.

Anne Richards at M&G Investments knows where national is knows it's a cheaper venue to run a firm. Is this the future, Anne Richards? Are all the teams like you, M&G, everybody else, is this the reality as you're going to leave the big cities?

RICHARDS: I don't think so. I think there are different reasons and different business models why people choose to do things. And I think you can overextrapolate what's going on. But it's -- for sure, you see that active management has been under pressure to prove itself in recent years. And I think -- we think that when you still continue to deliver the outcome that customer wants, that the client wants at the end of the day, the proposition is still very, very robust and compelling. I mean, we do have to all challenge ourselves on our cost base in order to make sure that we're delivering for those clients in the most efficient way that we can. And maybe that's an area where we've underinvested. But it's not just about location. It's much more innovative use of technology, for example, to run our operating systems and so forth.

KEENE: One that seems interesting to me, Anne Richards, is making money in the fixed income money management space. It's been a mystery to me for really ten years, even longer than that. What are the margins like in fixed income and how do you manage fixed income in the future?

RICHARDS: The key thing to being successful in fixed income markets in their broadest sense is the flexibility to go across the boundaries. So very, very simplistically, what I mean, by that is the ability to go long/short duration, long/short credit to across the boundaries between investment grade and high yield, even to go across the boundaries of public versus private markets. And the key money has been made across those boundaries and the ability to use that. Too often in fixed income space historically, we've tendered to have very, very narrow buckets. So you're really limited to one or two investment decisions. And if they go the wrong or the market goes the wrong way, then you have nowhere else to go. So flexibility, doing stuff that's harder to do in private markets, those are all areas where it has been possible to deliver really good returns, and actually I think will be in the future, but you need that flexibility.

LACQUA: And one what kind of impact has MiFID II has had at this point?

RICHARDS: It's sort of a little bit like the French Revolution. I think sometimes we feel it's a bit too early to say. The biggest impact that people will talk about is this fear that we've seen some liquidity, some trading capacity taken out of the market. It's not been a major issue yet. But I think there is a concern than in some kind of serious market correction, it might be difficult to find the volume and the liquidity in the market at a time when you need to in order to be able to shift things around. I think people are worried about it. There are some signs that that has happened. And I think we're all working behind the scenes to try and make sure that we find a way of staying within the MiFID rules, but nonetheless working constructively with regulators and others to make sure we don't lose that liquidity on moments of distress.

LACQUA: And, Anne, talking about your clients, are you pitching for the money from Lloyds that they took out as Standard Life Aberdeen?

RICHARDS: Okay. I would never talk publicly about anything that we would (inaudible), so I'm not going to -- I'm going to plead (inaudible) on that one, if I may.

LACQUA: Okay. Of course, that's a very elegant way of not answering a question and totally respect that.

KEENE: You just killed it there, Francine. That was just absolutely brilliant. (Inaudible) TV GO, if you're at M&G Investments and you need to dazzle Anne Richards this morning, you can do better -- look at this, come on.

LACQUA: So, I mean, you can't relax from the market then. Do you just kind of ignore the politics and focus on the fundamentals of BOE and the economy for investment decisions in the U.K.?

RICHARDS: Yes, I think you have to do it. I mean, you see, there are different parts of the market are doing well or better or worst. Retail really struggling high street on the one hand, on the other hand, you've got other parts of the market constructions doing a little bit better. So the economy, as a whole, has some good parts and some less good parts. We're not in Brexit yet. I mean, I think this is a thing that everybody sometimes forgets. We haven't had the Brexit. So we are still benefiting from all of the relationships that we currently have. So the question really is what happens once we move into that new world and we still have no real visibility in what that structure will look like. And I think the only real tangible thing that you've seen so far which gives you sometimes the measure that if you have seen investment flow, unquestionably, you're seeing decisions deferred, that's not to say it's all stopped, but you have seen that. So the longer term consequences of that if it's just a deferral and we'll come back again once we're through this period of uncertainty or actually hasn't permanently gone away, too early to say on that yet. So I think the -- between now and September-October when we get the final terms of what this limitation period looks like, what the final deal looks like, it's desperately important to get some visibility on that.

LACQUA: Anne, thank you so much. Anne Richards there, M&G Investments' Chief Executive, and David Merritt, Bloomberg's European News Director, joining us on Brexit.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Anne Richards and Francisco Jeronimo discuss economics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ANNE RICHARDS, CEO, M&G INVESTMENTS; AND FRANCISCO JERONIMO, SENIOR RESEARCH DIRECTOR, IDC; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB SURVEILLANCE

MAY 02, 2018

SPEAKERS: ANNE RICHARDS, CEO, M&G INVESTMENTS

FRANCISCO JERONIMO, SENIOR RESEARCH DIRECTOR, IDC

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: We're very pleased to be joined for the hour by Anne Richards. She is the Chief Executive of M&G Investments. And as always, you make us smarter, so thank you so much for coming on. What do you need from J. Powell? Is it more of an indication of kind of forward- looking of how many rate hikes? Is it something on the inverted yield curve and what that means as it happens or discontinuity?

ANNE RICHARDS, CEO, M&G INVESTMENTS: I think just no surprises. I think people are not expecting any fireworks and I think delivering that would be actually a good underpinning to the markets, particularly after the volatility that we saw in the first quarter, and that change and tone of the markets where you saw bonds and equities both moving down rather than up. So that increased volatility, that correlation of the wrong way, the way that people don't like correlations to go. So I think the fed here -- we've had those interest rate rises up to now, market isn't expecting anything, no surprises will be good results.

LACQUA: What is the fed's main dilemma right now?

RICHARDS: Well, I mean, feds always have dilemma about the path of growth, about the expectations of markets, about inflation. Actually, corporate earnings are doing pretty well. They've been ahead of expectations. Inflation, we've got enough inflation. It doesn't look like we have too much inflation. We're kind of on target on inflation, I would say. So I don't think there are too many dilemmas. I think that the challenge is simply don't do a misstep that spooks anybody at this point, particularly when you set this in a wider context, so a lot of uncertainty around trade, around some of the geopolitical relationships. I think the mantra is don't mess up here, stead as she goes.

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Anne, when you look at the M&G Investments and when you look at the mathematics of bond bear markets, I believe that is yield higher, prices lower. It's never a smooth gradient, there're always jump conditions. What are the kinds of jump conditions that we could see in the bond market where we get jumps in yield and lower prices suddenly?

RICHARDS: So it's this -- always against this backdrop, there're stuffs that could happen that would shock the market into doing different things. It's very hard to predict what those are in advance, which is a tripe thing to say. We all know that. But we have -- we are moving this year from a position of net bond purchasing by central banks to a situation where we've got net bond issuance right around the world. And the market is still adjusting to what that looks and feel like. Actually, you've got a big buyer who is no longer going to be buying, if you like, right around the world. And I think that is the tipping point. It's about the demand and supply for those bond issues that are out there. So I think, to me, that is the big one that we're navigating this year. It is a different backdrop to bond markets, in general.

KEENE: Yes. Francine, this is really important on what she just said. Anne Richards goes down microeconomic principles when you look at a big macroeconomic view from 30,000 feet, I think. I really agree with that, that this is about microeconomics here forward for Chairman Powell.

LACQUA: It is, Tom. But if we bring it back to the markets, Anne, what do clients want? I mean, what kind of strategies do they ask of you?

RICHARDS: So I think smoothing has definitely been something. I mean, people have got quite used to this relatively low volatile world, at least in listed markets and so -- and conventional markets. You could argue, there has been a lot of volatility. Non-conventional markets like digital currencies and Bitcoin, all of that sort of stuff. But conventional markets, volatility really had become very subdued. And suddenly there's been that shock back into volatility worlds. So removing that volatility, so trying to seek out where you have counter-correlated assets to kind of smooth that path is definitely one of the things that people are out there. Having said that, I think a lot of people are look at the underlying power of earnings that we've got through coming from the corporate sector. And looking at the trade-off of the risks that you now see and still not again a lot of real yield out of bond markets and still getting quite a powerhouse in terms of earning growth from equity markets and saying, actually, the price of our extra volatility and equity markets might be worth paying because you can really see the fundamentals coming through. So I think there's a number of -- it really depends always on utility curves, preferences. What is it that is most important to individuals? And there's no one summary you can say, all individuals want this or all individuals want that. So I think those are two of themes that we would see coming through in conversations with clients.

LACQUA: I mean, has the conversation shifted in the last couple of weeks because there's a little bit of a slowdown in economic growth worldwide? And actually, what does that mean again for a market sentiment in the future and the correlation with monetary policy?

RICHARDS: It's fascinating actually. See, people -- how quickly sentiment changes and what people talk about. So some of those things that I just perceive that people are suddenly talking about again, gold has come back, but inflation, gold. Suddenly -- we didn't talk about that six months ago. Suddenly, that's back on the conversation again. So that's one thing. I think that the oil price, frankly, is another. You've seen the oil price, which everybody said was very subdued for a very long period of time. And it sort of snuck up on us instead of gradually, gradually, gradually been moving into territory where despite the fact that you've not seen the investment really start go back in again. Actually, the economics start to make that more appealing. So there's mentioned in conversations around oil price commodities and the knock-on effects of that. So I think we're going to see a change in tone in some of those conversations. The whole tech conversation of what does a successful business model look like in technology. Again, 2016-2017, big tech was winner almost regardless of what it did. Much more discrimination coming into the conversations with clients about what a good business model is, what a bad business model is and (inaudible).

KEENE: Anne Richards, Megan Greene writing in the FT today on where is inflation, we're all waiting for it. I guess we'll hear about it in the non-press conference today at the debt (ph) meeting. Where is the inflation?

RICHARDS: Gosh, what an interesting question. Inflation comes in all sorts of different places and unexpected places, I think. So conventional inflation is varying country-by-country, market-by-market quite significantly, oil price will be feeding through into inflation numbers, that's absolutely the case. But on the other hand, if you see what's happening on the retail high street, you can see the high street is challenged still by falling process in many areas, where on the other side coin, you've got internet prices actually going up in some respect. So you've got some quite an interesting contrast there. So I think, overall in inflation, it's still a very difficult picture, I think, for anybody to grasp the totality of it. So oil price starting to feed through is definitely one, and some of the big currency moves, you're actually seeing currency induced inflation rather than fundamental underlying inflation.

KEENE: Exactly. Well, that's one of our themes here through Surveillance this morning. Anne Richards with us with the M&G Investment.

LACQUA: We're back with Anne Richards, Chief Executive of M&G Investments. Anne, when you look at again what your clients want, how you position on your portfolios, trade tensions seemed to be on the back of it because at least Steve Mnuchin is showing up in a couple of hours I think to try and discuss, is this still the main risk for the world economy or is it monetary policy?

RICHARDS: It's (inaudible). So I think trade is clearly out there as something that people are concerned about because the global economy, in terms of the totality of the pie, if you like, has been expanded over recent decades by global trades. That's been the big driver of much of the global expansion. So if that is really under threat, then there is a risk that we end up fighting over a smaller -- a share of the smaller pie as opposed to it. And I think that is the concern that's out there. Having said all of that, the way that America has been conducting trade policy negotiations, and indeed other international negotiations has been about ripping up the playbook, throwing everything up in the air, getting everybody uncertain and then coming to a compromise at the last minute, and you can see that. And a classic example of that is the way the North and South Korea conversations are going. Whereas if you think back to last year, it was all about who was going to hit the big the red button first. And now, we actually have come far farther than anyone ever anticipated than we would have done a year ago. So I think there's a little bit around this whole global trade tariffs conversation which will affect -- will be affected in the same way ultimately. On the European thing, I just absolutely do not believe that the U.S. wants to mess up relationship with Europe. But President Trump clearly wants to get the maximum that it possibly can out of any bartering that it does with Europe, hence, the conversations that have been had with Mr. Macron, with Mrs. Merkel over the last week or so. So I think that's what we're going to play out and I think most of that, as when we look at it, think that that is the central scenario. But in that sense (ph), there are risks.

LACQUA: Do you worry about European growth having peaked? We're seeing -- again, the data is not that clear actually, right? It depends on kind of some of the PMIs are better than expected in certain countries, worse than expecting others, should we assume that it doesn't get any better than this for your portfolios?

RICHARDS: Well, I think on Europe. I mean, I think there are still a lot of things that are going in the right direction. But there have been a few things which have come together simultaneously. People are starting to get concerned about the impact of Brexit on Mainland Europe. That wasn't a concern. That is beginning to be a little bit of a concern. You will see people deferring or shaping some of their investment plans because of that. So that will have a feed through on that. The fact that in Germany and France and Italy, so with the big three countries there, there are political tensions and relatively unclear and insecure governments in different forms and shapes in place there. Again, it doesn't help the view that we're going to get a kind of coordinated negotiated settlement on anything very much. So there were a few things in the background that just make people feel a little bit less comfortable than they did six months ago in Europe. But actually, the direction of travel is still okay.

KEENE: Anne Richards, Martin Wolf and the FT with a brilliant walkthrough of China's attitude as the U.S. officials travel to China, I guess, to have a big argument on trade. What does it mean for your international investment at M&G? Do you lighten up or is this an opportunity to acquire Pacific Rim shares?

RICHARDS: So, look, on the whole China story and what is being driven through that China story, I think the -- you are seeing a change yet again in the outreach that's coming out of China. And that is very, very powerful. So the ability of business to get direct access to markets that it was not able to get direct access to before in China has been -- that's a very significant announcement. The fact that she is in place for much longer than might have been anticipated and will be continuing to drive forward in that economic empowering, I think, creates a very positive backdrop to what's going on in China. So I think we would remain positive on the direction of travel

LACQUA: Anne, thank you so much. Anne Richards there of M&G stays with us.

Joining us now is Francisco Jeronimo, IDC Senior Research Director for European mobile devices and Anne Richards of M&G Investments where she's Chief Executive. So thank you both for coming on the program. Francisco, what do we learn about Apple?

FRANCISCO JERONIMO, SENIOR RESEARCH DIRECTOR, IDC: We learned that a powerful brand continues to perform when they continue to deliver value that consumers perceived as something that improves overtime. And after ten years when the first -- after the first -- the launch of the first iPhone, and when the market is already contracting. And then last year, the decline for the first time, the smart phone, Apple delivering these kinds of results at a higher price point, it's remarkable and definitely a stellar quarter for Apple.

LACQUA: Francisco, let me talk to you about the iPhone and then I want to ask Anne a little bit about the financial surrounding Apple. But if you look at the iPhone year-on-year revenue growth -- Tom, bear with me. I know you don't like candle charts, but this is a really good one. We heard from the Chief Executive of Apple saying, look, iPhone X was stellar, best performing, but that's what you'd expect. How does he continue on this trend in the quarters to come?

JERONIMO: That's a challenge for them. Of course, it's a challenge. But it really shows that the brand proposition and then the perception of the consumers and enterprises also have about Apple is not just about the good looking iPhones, it's about everything that comes with the device. The ecosystem and all the services and also a very important topic that he mentioned in the call, the privacy and security, and indeed IDC did a recent survey to enterprise in Europe. And we found out that the top reason that why enterprises choose an iPhone is because of security and the perception that an iPhone brings around security. And this is a very important value for consumers and enterprises in the smart phone, particularly nowadays with all the news and the candles (ph) around privacy leaks and all of those problems.

LACQUA: Yes. We can take about Facebook. We also need to talk about Snap. I know I'm going to find Tom on Snap. I'm sure it's like #tomtom or something like that. He's keeping it secret. Anne, when you look at Apple, they have a lot of cash. And finally, they're returning it to shareholders. Do you like the stock (inaudible)?

RICHARDS: So hundred billion coming back to shareholders, I mean, that can be quite nice. That could be quite nice for markets that's putting a lot of liquidity into the system. There's a lot of central banks that would like that sort of money, I think, knocking around. So I think that it's tremendous. But I think the thing you have to remember with Apple is its maturity as a business is showing through. And I don't mean maturity in terms of the product range. But actually it's grown up company that has proper mechanisms in place. It's not trying to make this up as it has got larger -- unexpectedly larger, like some of the newer competitors in the general social media tech space. You really see that strength coming through. And what's fascinating to me is that it's still innovating but its innovation is not a product book. It is in that ecosystem, exactly as you mentioned. It is in the services that it's persuading us all to subscribe to. And it's been very, very successful in doing that. Service revenue is now really significant proportion of the overall mix. So I think when you look in the round (ph), I mean, Apple at this valuation at this point, it takes a strong stomach. We don't have very much exposure to it. But nonetheless, I think you've got to give credit to it for its ability to continue to innovate in different ways with this business model.

KEENE: That was so brilliant, folks, with the mathematics of Anne Richards that we're going to stop the show, show a chart and continue with the mathematician from Edinboro and the engineer from Edinboro. She used the word, maturity. Okay. So, Anne, this on a second derivative basis is logged (ph) concave. The media is hardwired to long convex, IDC, Francisco's company has been brilliant with a tempered view. Is Apply basically tending towards a utility-like cash flow, Anne Richards, which goes to the maturity of that concave chart? I mean, they're not the normal growth company anymore, are they? They are just, as you say, a mature company.

RICHARDS: So they're a mature company. I would probably go with the view that they're a mature and growing company, so a company that is not going through the stellar almost exponential growth that you see, and we might come and talk back about Snap and how that works in reverse as well. But I think you've got to give a lot of credit to Apple that it is managing to innovate its business model and that is coming through in a much more robust and sustainable model than you see in some of the (inaudible). Now, valuation is a different thing. But nonetheless, (inaudible) business model looks sustainable.

KEENE: Okay. This is brilliant, folks. We've got a major financial accent in Anne Richards and Francisco Jeronimo working with IDC. Francisco, help us with the unit partial differentials as you go up the cell phone price point. The Apple gloom and doom crew says the iPhone X costs too much, baloney, they're selling them like crazy. Where is the tip point per unit? Is it $900? Is it $700? Where is the tip point where expensive phones become a gravy train?

JERONIMO: The tipping point is when there is no additional value that consumers are willing or are getting from a product. The criticisms that we hear today about the iPhone X is exactly the same criticism that we heard in 2007 when they launched the first iPhone. Everyone was saying, this is crazy, launching a smart phone at this price point when the average selling smart phone at that time were much lower, and it's exactly the same. Of course, it doesn't Apple can continue to stretch the prices up because there's definitely a limit where consumers will ask themselves whether it's worth paying for that kind of device or not. But at the moment, Apple continues to do very well and the $1,000 price tag continues to be an achievable average selling price for their projects in the next quarters. However, the market is contracting. So even if Apple wants to sell less products or sell less products at a higher price point, there's a limit because the market is not growing for every single person around the world and in regions where people cannot afford these kinds price points as Apple continues to do and invest in the older versions of their devices and pushing those previous to those consumers at lower price points. But clearly, if the value is there, consumers are willing to pay.

LACQUA: Anne, talk to me about Facebook. So they're going into a dating app which actually a lot of their dating ventures (ph) are more (inaudible) about. And this is Snap. So Snap was down, I think, 18% of premarket trade because their redesign isn't working. I mean, what happened to Snap?

RICHARDS: Well, it's burning through cash at a rate. It's got a lot of cash on its balance sheet. So I think it's a time cash burn story. Can it turn around the use of experience in such a way that it actually starts to put on user growth at the same rate as it did before and get the ad revenue going to support it before it runs out of cash? And we've seen loads of business. They're not usually this big when they go through this but this is a very classic program. And I think that's the situation that we're in with Snap at the moment.

KEENE: Well, go ahead, Anne. Please continue.

RICHARDS: No, I was going to say what I think what's interesting when you see that the Facebook, the dating app, and we see Google's recent announcement, even you see Apple talking about what it's doing with Apple Watch and thinking about health. The ecosystem argument is definitely leeching out all of these companies and thinking how do we expand from our simple one product, one business model ad revenue fuelled model into something that is expanding. And I think at this stage, we don't know who is going to be the winner in this. But certainly the companies that are trying to do something different are more likely to succeed than those that aren't.

KEENE: I can't say enough how valuable this was. Anne Richards with us with M&G. Francisco Jeronimo, thank you so much, with IDC. I look forward to speaking to you with John Farrell on Bloomberg Radio here in a bit.

Anne Richards at M&G Investments knows where national is knows it's a cheaper venue to run a firm. Is this the future, Anne Richards? Are all the teams like you, M&G, everybody else, is this the reality as you're going to leave the big cities?

RICHARDS: I don't think so. I think there are different reasons and different business models why people choose to do things. And I think you can overextrapolate what's going on. But it's -- for sure, you see that active management has been under pressure to prove itself in recent years. And I think -- we think that when you still continue to deliver the outcome that customer wants, that the client wants at the end of the day, the proposition is still very, very robust and compelling. I mean, we do have to all challenge ourselves on our cost base in order to make sure that we're delivering for those clients in the most efficient way that we can. And maybe that's an area where we've underinvested. But it's not just about location. It's much more innovative use of technology, for example, to run our operating systems and so forth.

KEENE: One that seems interesting to me, Anne Richards, is making money in the fixed income money management space. It's been a mystery to me for really ten years, even longer than that. What are the margins like in fixed income and how do you manage fixed income in the future?

RICHARDS: The key thing to being successful in fixed income markets in their broadest sense is the flexibility to go across the boundaries. So very, very simplistically, what I mean, by that is the ability to go long/short duration, long/short credit to across the boundaries between investment grade and high yield, even to go across the boundaries of public versus private markets. And the key money has been made across those boundaries and the ability to use that. Too often in fixed income space historically, we've tendered to have very, very narrow buckets. So you're really limited to one or two investment decisions. And if they go the wrong or the market goes the wrong way, then you have nowhere else to go. So flexibility, doing stuff that's harder to do in private markets, those are all areas where it has been possible to deliver really good returns, and actually I think will be in the future, but you need that flexibility.

LACQUA: And one what kind of impact has MiFID II has had at this point?

RICHARDS: It's sort of a little bit like the French Revolution. I think sometimes we feel it's a bit too early to say. The biggest impact that people will talk about is this fear that we've seen some liquidity, some trading capacity taken out of the market. It's not been a major issue yet. But I think there is a concern than in some kind of serious market correction, it might be difficult to find the volume and the liquidity in the market at a time when you need to in order to be able to shift things around. I think people are worried about it. There are some signs that that has happened. And I think we're all working behind the scenes to try and make sure that we find a way of staying within the MiFID rules, but nonetheless working constructively with regulators and others to make sure we don't lose that liquidity on moments of distress.

LACQUA: And, Anne, talking about your clients, are you pitching for the money from Lloyds that they took out as Standard Life Aberdeen?

RICHARDS: Okay. I would never talk publicly about anything that we would (inaudible), so I'm not going to -- I'm going to plead (inaudible) on that one, if I may.

LACQUA: Okay. Of course, that's a very elegant way of not answering a question and totally respect that.

KEENE: You just killed it there, Francine. That was just absolutely brilliant. (Inaudible) TV GO, if you're at M&G Investments and you need to dazzle Anne Richards this morning, you can do better -- look at this, come on.

LACQUA: So, I mean, you can't relax from the market then. Do you just kind of ignore the politics and focus on the fundamentals of BOE and the economy for investment decisions in the U.K.?

RICHARDS: Yes, I think you have to do it. I mean, you see, there are different parts of the market are doing well or better or worst. Retail really struggling high street on the one hand, on the other hand, you've got other parts of the market constructions doing a little bit better. So the economy, as a whole, has some good parts and some less good parts. We're not in Brexit yet. I mean, I think this is a thing that everybody sometimes forgets. We haven't had the Brexit. So we are still benefiting from all of the relationships that we currently have. So the question really is what happens once we move into that new world and we still have no real visibility in what that structure will look like. And I think the only real tangible thing that you've seen so far which gives you sometimes the measure that if you have seen investment flow, unquestionably, you're seeing decisions deferred, that's not to say it's all stopped, but you have seen that. So the longer term consequences of that if it's just a deferral and we'll come back again once we're through this period of uncertainty or actually hasn't permanently gone away, too early to say on that yet. So I think the -- between now and September-October when we get the final terms of what this limitation period looks like, what the final deal looks like, it's desperately important to get some visibility on that.

LACQUA: Anne, thank you so much. Anne Richards there, M&G Investments' Chief Executive, and David Merritt, Bloomberg's European News Director, joining us on Brexit.
